Bug.Summery: Deploy - get large number of files triggers server limit
Bug.WithStack:
I set up a project with target site defined to be ftp://rogue.oti.com and tried to get the site. This triggered the error shown in the attached bitmap. This does not happen why I get the site using dreamweaver. I can only suspect that maybe we keep a single session open and they open a new session for each file? Created attachment 1132 Bitmap showing error Actually now I am wondering if it is failing randomly and it is not a server limit error at all. I just tried another directory and it failed after 7 files (see attached bitmap).
Created attachment 1133 Bitmap showing second error after only 7 files It's not a server limit. This is the message that you get when you log out of the FTP server; apparently we are mis-parsing it as an error when in fact it's purely informational. I think there may have been a PR about this somewhere. Oddly it seems to only happen when getting certain directories...

Bug.Summery: Chevrons do not stay pushed while popup menu is displayed
Bug.WithStack:
The default behavior for chevrons on a win32 platform is for the chevron to stay pushed while the popup menu is displayed.
This can be fixed with a simple code change. The RBN_CHEVRONPUSHED message needs to be processed immediately for the chevron to stay pushed instead of being posted to the queue for later processing.
In the CoolBar.wmNotifyChild() method, changing child.postEvent() to child.sendEvent() will rectify the problem. Steve, since we are not going to fix Bug#18403 we also should close this PR as WONTFIX.
Just to let you know, the fix posted here will cause the chevron to stay pushed as expected, but if you have multiples chevrons showing at the same time and click on them all they will all stay pushed, only one (the last) will be showing the menu though.
Agree.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The default behavior for chevrons on a win32 platform is for the chevron to stay pushed while the popup menu is displayed.

Just to let you know, the fix posted here will cause the chevron to stay pushed as expected, but if you have multiples chevrons showing at the same time and click on them all they will all stay pushed, only one (the last) will be showing the menu though.
Agree.

Bug.Summery: ToolItems with the DROP_DOWN style should stay pushed
Bug.WithStack:
The default behavior for ToolItems with a DROP_DOWN style on a win32 platform is for the arrow to stay pushed while the popup menu is displayed.
This can be fixed with a simple code change. The TBN_DROPDOWN message needs to be processed immediately for the arrow part of the ToolItem to stay pushed instead of being posted to the queue for later processing.
In the ToolBar.wmNotifyChild() method, changing child.postEvent() to child.sendEvent() will rectify the problem. Thanks. You are right but there are issues surrounding send vs post for SWT.Selection events. It think your change is good and should go in but it is way to late in the freeze cycle for R2.0 to risk it. we should re-consider this for 2.1
Changing this the post to the send will no longer fix the problem for menus in 2.1 because Menu.setVisible() defers the menu pop up to the event loop. This is to be consistent with the other platforms where pop up menus do not start a modal menu loop in the application code but instead, run from Display.readAndDispatch()).
I don't believe we should change this (sorry Rob).

The default behavior for ToolItems with a DROP_DOWN style on a win32 platform is for the arrow to stay pushed while the popup menu is displayed.
This can be fixed with a simple code change. The TBN_DROPDOWN message needs to be processed immediately for the arrow part of the ToolItem to stay pushed instead of being posted to the queue for later processing.
In the ToolBar.wmNotifyChild() method, changing child.postEvent() to child.sendEvent() will rectify the problem. Thanks. You are right but there are issues surrounding send vs post for SWT.Selection events. It think your change is good and should go in but it is way to late in the freeze cycle for R2.0 to risk it. we should re-consider this for 2.1

I don't believe we should change this (sorry Rob).

Bug.Summery: [ExternalTools] Run External - Command variables not working?

Lines.Line: 1. i will log the leading slash comment and the selection bug to platform ui.
2. i will log the comment regarding confusing terminology to core resources.
3. i will log a note to platform docs requesting special attention to
explaining variable names and the issue with filenames containing spaces.
Quoting the argument fixed the problem.
However users are going to run into trouble for the reasons you outline:
1) Without quotes some apps don't work and you have no clue why. I wonder why
we don't just insert the quotes into the text area for the arguments by
default? The user can always remove them.

Bug.WithStack:
As far as I can tell, no command variables are being passed to the external program. I tried both current project location and selected resource location. I set up an external program with both c:\windows\write.exe and c:\windows\command.com and neither seems to be passed the variable contents. Although if I type a specific non-variable parameter into the "Tool Arguments" field, that works. Build was 0530 integration build.
Need to ensure that all the variables we claim to support are working for F2. Please verify. Checked build 0609, using NT and Win98. As far as I can tell this is *not* working. I configured an external tool definition for wordpad.exe (write.exe on win98). I tried both the following variables: selected resource location selected resource full path
It appears that no parameters are being passed to the program. If I type a constant parameter into the dialog then it works.
i wrote a program, c:\args.cmd, which looks like this:
echo [0] %0 echo [1] %1 echo [2] %2 echo [3] %3 echo [4] %4 echo [5] %5 echo [6] %6 echo [7] %7 echo [8] %8 echo [9] %9
a created ten tools from this program, one for each of the first ten variables as the tool's single argument. from my workspace (built from importing the plugins), i selected in navigator a file resource: "plugin.xml" under "org.junit".
i ran each tool on this selection with the following results (as displayed in the log console; irrelevant details omitted):
args ${workspace_loc} [0] c:\args.cmd [1] C:/eclipse-SDK-20020607-win32/eclipse/workspace
args ${project_loc} [0] c:\args.cmd [1] C:/eclipse-SDK-20020607-win32/eclipse/workspace/org.junit
args ${container_loc} [0] c:\args.cmd [1] C:/eclipse-SDK-20020607-win32/eclipse/workspace/org.junit
args ${resource_loc} [0] c:\args.cmd [1] C:/eclipse-SDK-20020607-win32/eclipse/workspace/org.junit/plugin.xml
args ${project_path} [0] c:\args.cmd [1] /org.junit
args ${container_path} [0] c:\args.cmd [1] /org.junit
args ${resource_path} [0] c:\args.cmd [1] /org.junit/plugin.xml
args ${project_name} [0] c:\args.cmd [1] org.junit
args ${container_name} [0] c:\args.cmd [1] org.junit
args ${resource_name} [0] c:\args.cmd [1] plugin.xml
wordpad:
now i created two tools using wordpad (C:\Program Files\Windows NT\Accessories\wordpad.exe), the first using ${resource_loc} as its argument. with the same selection as above, wordpad launches the file correctly. i am not able to repeat your problem for this case.
the second, using ${resource_path} as its argument, causes wordpad to launch, but wordpad is unable to launch the file so it starts with a blank document. this is also correct behavior according to the above tests. wordpad cannot find "/org.junit/plugin.xml"
(note: it is unfortunate that the full path variables always have a leading slash, otherwise i could have been able to launch in this case by specifying ${workspace_loc} as the working directory.)
there are a two areas where you may have had problems (i stumbled on both of them myself):
potential issue #1: paths with spaces
eclipse has no problem executing applications with spaces in the path. quotes are not required. interpretation of arguments, of course, is up to the tool itself, and occasionally a tool will fail on a filename containing spaces unless it is explicitly quoted. eclipse does not seem to quote arguments with spaces, and i feel that this is correct behavior. wordpad will fail on filenames containing spaces unless explicitely quoted. this may have happened in your case.
potential issue #2: selection bug
try the args ${resource_loc} example above again. make sure to select a resource first. notice that the current view (probably navigator if you just selected a resource) deactivates when the tool is run. when the tool finishes, the view doesn't reactivate. notice the resource is still selected, but colored gray. try running the tool again. the argument expands to an empty string as the view does not return a selected resource. try this with the wordpad ${resource_loc} example and you will get a blank document.
finally, a note about the variable terminology:
as a regular user, my first thought is that "full path" and "location" should be swapped. "full path" intuitively means an absolute path on a file system, while "location" is a more abstract notion - more useful a term to describe a relative position within a domain-specific semantic construct like 'workspace' external tools is not to blame: during variable expansion it correctly delegates to IResource.getFullPath() and IResource.getLocation() respectively, and i think the ui is correct to match its terminology to core resources public api. i do find it curious why core resources didn't swap these terms.
summary: 1. i will log the leading slash comment and the selection bug to platform ui. 2. i will log the comment regarding confusing terminology to core resources. 3. i will log a note to platform docs requesting special attention to explaining variable names and the issue with filenames containing spaces. Quoting the argument fixed the problem. However users are going to run into trouble for the reasons you outline: 1) Without quotes some apps don't work and you have no clue why. I wonder why we don't just insert the quotes into the text area for the arguments by default? The user can always remove them.
2) The terminology for the arguments is confusing and conterintuitive - we need a better way to indicate what exactly will be passed as the argument - perhaps we could show what would be passed given the current selection, or provide a test area so you can click on something and see what happens.
Actually, it only worked the first time. After some experimentation I discovered I had to re-click on the item in the list to make it work again. I am reopening the report because there is still a real problem here.
Ryan was looking at quoting the arguments being passed (both for location and path variables). It was not part of friday's build.
I agree, we exposed the core terminology in the UI - coming up with better names for these would help.
The lost of focus may come from the use of a progress monitor. This problem may go away if we can run without a progress monitor. The variables are now working. The selection problem and the terminology will have to wait until post 2.0. Post 2.0. Reopened for investigation This is fixed in the new external tool support.
Note: new external tool work is not yet released to the head stream and won't for a while yet.

Bug.Summery: Quick fix finds problem with System.out.
Bug.WithStack: On a new line type "System.out.". Note "System" is squiggled. Put cursor over System. Nothing. Put cursor over light bulb. Nothing. Click in System and press Ctrl-1. "No corrections available" Huh? Please don't squiggle things unless you can explain why. I wonder whether the override indicator is the problem. Can you run the scenario again but with the override indicator turned off: Preferences>Java>Appearance: Show Override Indicator in outline and hierarchy annotation is for another bug... It apparently depends on the context (which I've forgotten). I initially did this because someone else reported that System.out. didn't provide any code assist. And sure enough, code assist came up only sporadically, but the odd error squiggling was consistent. Now I can't repro it at all. :( cannot reproduce neither, pls reopen when you see the problem again
Bug.WithOutStack: On a new line type "System.out.". Note "System" is squiggled. Put cursor over System. Nothing. Put cursor over light bulb. Nothing. Click in System and press Ctrl-1. "No corrections available" Huh? Please don't squiggle things unless you can explain why. I wonder whether the override indicator is the problem. Can you run the scenario again but with the override indicator turned off: Preferences>Java>Appearance: Show Override Indicator in outline and hierarchy annotation is for another bug... Bug.Summery: External JAR refresh - caching problem

source_code.code: // handle open and closing of a solution or project
// we don't show the contents of a compilation or IClassFile,

Lines.Line: 0. Import x.jar from external location and add the JAR to the build path
==> x.jar as INTERNAL JAR
1. Drill into a package where class C is visible
2. Remove x.jar from build path (not from project)
3. Add x.jar as EXTERNAL JAR
4. Drill into the package where class C is visible
5. Delete C from the external JAR
6. Refresh the project
==> C remains visible
0. Import p1.zip from external location and add the JAR to the build path
==> p1.zip as INTERNAL JAR
1. Drill into a package where class Y is visible
2. Remove p1.zip from build path (not from project)
3. Add p1.zip as EXTERNAL JAR
4. Drill into the package where class Y is visible
5. Switch p1.zip with the one not containing X and Y
6. Refresh the project
==> Y is gone
0. Export attached x.jar to c:\
1. Fresh workspace
2. Create Ja project "JUnit"
3. Import x.jar from file system c:\ (as single file)
4. Add x.jar to the build path
5. Open junit.samples.VectorTest
6. Remove x.jar from the build path (press OK)
7. Add external c:\JAR x.jar to the build path
8. Open junit.samples.VectorTest
9. Open c:\x.jar with winzip, delete VectorTest.java, close winzip
10. Select project "JUnit" in packages view press F5
==> VectorTest remains in Packages view
Note: Close the project, reopen it: now VectorTest is gone

Bug.Summery: win32 + cygwin + eclipse cdt problems
Bug.WithStack:
first - I create new project and added main.cpp file:
#include <iostream>
int main() { cout << "Eclipse says hello." << endl; return 0; }
Then I tried to Autoconf->Configure->Program - all passes ok, but then it reaches end - I got error:
checking for ANSI C header files... (cached) yes configure: creating ./config.status config.status: creating Makefile config.status: creating \ config.status: error: cannot find input file: \.in
Also I have seen some interlocking in cygwin and cmd.exe processes - and think this problem maybe in Eclipse CDT usage of them. The generated Makefile.am(s) contains lines like the following:
SOURCES = dir1 \ dir2 \ . . etc..
that uses the "\" continuation character which autoconf/automake on cygwin - for some reason - does not accept. So, check all your Makefile.am(s) - you will find one in each dir- and if you have lines containing the continuation character, changed as follows: SOURCES = dir1 dir2 . ..... etc. This, I believe, has been resolved in the latest autoconf automake versions - 2.53 and 1.6 - although they contain lots of problems and I don't recommend using them at this moment. Hope this solve the problem but If you find that it did not, you may reopen the bug. LATER/REMIND are deprecated. Changing to reopened milestone '--'
Bug.WithOutStack:
first - I create new project and added main.cpp file:
#include <iostream>
int main() { cout << "Eclipse says hello." << endl; return 0; }
Then I tried to Autoconf->Configure->Program - all passes ok, but then it reaches end - I got error:
checking for ANSI C header files... (cached) yes configure: creating ./config.status config.status: creating Makefile config.status: creating \ config.status: error: cannot find input file: \.in
Also I have seen some interlocking in cygwin and cmd.exe processes - and think this problem maybe in Eclipse CDT usage of them. The generated Makefile.am(s) contains lines like the following:
SOURCES = dir1 \ dir2 \ . . etc..
that uses the "\" continuation character which autoconf/automake on cygwin - for some reason - does not accept. So, check all your Makefile.am(s) - you will find one in each dir- and if you have lines containing the continuation character, changed as follows: SOURCES = dir1 dir2 . ..... etc. This, I believe, has been resolved in the latest autoconf automake versions - 2.53 and 1.6 - although they contain lots of problems and I don't recommend using them at this moment. Hope this solve the problem but If you find that it did not, you may reopen the bug. LATER/REMIND are deprecated. Changing to reopened milestone '--'

Bug.Summery: FTP: DBCS file name put will be bogus

Lines.Line: 1) right click for a project and select "Deploy" - "Configure Site..."
2) Select FTP for a repository site
3) input URL, User and password for the FTP server
4) right click for a DBCS named file and select "Deploy" - "Put"

Bug.WithStack:
Build 0530, WindowsXP Japanese, FTP server AIX 4.3.3 Ja_JP locale
STEPS 1) right click for a project and select "Deploy" - "Configure Site..." 2) Select FTP for a repository site 3) input URL, User and password for the FTP server 4) right click for a DBCS named file and select "Deploy" - "Put"
The file name was created as UTF-8, so the name has been bogus. ftp from WinXP console successfully can put the DBCS file name. User is using target management plugin with FTP target provider. Moving to Platform/VCM for comment. James to investigate Class ControlConnection uses an InputStream/OutputStream pair. I suspect it should be using a Reader/Writer pair instead, with the appropriate encoding set. We do a similar thing for CVS. Shouldn't be hard to fix, would require some testing. (reworded title to denote FTP specific) Fix is ready. Verified by MV. Released. verified with 20020623

Bug.Summery: search: searchDeclarationsOfReferencedTypes reports import declarations
Dirty editor not closed when deleting project

Lines.Line: 1. Create Java project 'Test'
2. Create compilation unit X.java
3. Edit X.java and make the editor dirty (so leave it unsaved)
4. Delete project 'Test'
Observe: The editor is left opened.

Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020530
1. Create Java project 'Test' 2. Create compilation unit X.java 3. Edit X.java and make the editor dirty (so leave it unsaved) 4. Delete project 'Test' Observe: The editor is left opened.
If you give it focus, you get an error dialog: Problems managing bookmarks. Reason: Resource /Test/X.java does not exist. not closing the editor is good since it ensures that the user doesn't loose changes, but the exception should not happen. It is a duplicate of another bug. The managing bookmark problem has been solved. Leaving dirty editor open is the intended behavior as it avoids unintentional loss of data.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20020530
1. Create Java project 'Test' 2. Create compilation unit X.java 3. Edit X.java and make the editor dirty (so leave it unsaved) 4. Delete project 'Test' Observe: The editor is left opened.

Reason: Resource /Test/X.java does not exist. not closing the editor is good since it ensures that the user doesn't loose changes, but the exception should not happen. It is a duplicate of another bug. The managing bookmark problem has been solved. Leaving dirty editor open is the intended behavior as it avoids unintentional loss of data.

Bug.Summery: The marker bar popup does not allow to enter watchpoints
Bug.WithStack:
If you click on the marker bar in a field line a popup appears that lets you add a breakpoint. If no executable code exists in this line a breakpoint is added in the closer location. It would be more useful in that circumnstance to allow entering a watchpoint instead of a breakpoint. If that is not possible or in addition it would be nice to add this option to the contextual menu when clicking on a field. Now the only way to add a watchpont is from the Run menu.
Furthermore if a watchpoint exists and you click on it the popup uses the "breakpoint" term instead of "watchpoint". It is unlikely at this stage we will be adding new features (adding a watchpoint from the ruler context menu).
It would be possible to label the actions with "* Watchpoint" instead of "* Breakpoint".
Note that watchpoints can be added via the context menu when a field is selected. For example, in the outliner or the packages view. Feature request. Deferred. Re-open for 3.0 *** Bug 31579 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Deferred (again) re-open to mark as dup
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 13368 ***

Bug.Summery: Java, Java Example and Properties editors not registered as default
Bug.WithStack:
The Java, Java Example Editor (found in plugin org.eclipse.ui.examples.javaeditor), and Properties file editors are not registered as default. We are seeing editor registration conflicts with other editors, and believe they can be most easily resolved by setting the above editors as default. The Java editor is registered as default editor since 20020529.
The Java examples editor should be registered as the default, it doesn't make sense to do so for an example.
Finally, the properties should not be registered as a default, since it is just the vanilla text editor.
pls reopen if you think this problem isn't sufficently addressed.

Bug.Summery: ScrolledComposite with LayoutManager is VERY slow in iPAQ

source_code.code: void setBounds (int x, int y, int width, int height, int flags) {

Lines.Line: - check if something specifically wrong on WinCE
- possibly due to GridLayout being very heavy (synchronization/hash
table/vector) - verify

Bug.WithStack:
I've tried the examples for the ScrolledComposite from the javadoc on the iPAQ an it is very slow. After touching the slider it took 2 sec to move the slider to the new position and another 6 sec to scroll the content of the widget. I've tried the old examples (displaying 10 buttons) and the new one (two ScrolledComposite and one button to add buttons to these widgets). Then I modified the old examples (deleting the LayoutManager) and placed the buttons by myself (setLocation). This helps. Now I can move the slider while the content is repainted. Seems that the LayoutManager is too slow for the iPAQ. I'm using: iPAQ with pocketPC2002 swt-win32-2040.dll j9
You can find the examples in the old and the new javadoc of ScrolledComposite. Wow, that's slow alright! We're in the midst of our R2.0 freeze test cycle, so we may not be able to do anything about this for the next two or three weeks, but we'll definately take a look at it.
It may be that there is actually something wrong with the way our code is interacting with WinCE, as apposed to it just being slow because of VM, clock speed, etc. differences.
CC to investigate.
TBD - check if something specifically wrong on WinCE - possibly due to GridLayout being very heavy (synchronization/hash table/vector) - verify
- Some personal tips to workaround it - I recommend avoiding the ScrolledComposite on PocketPC. - rearrange in different Composite instead when possible. If you have large/variable amount of data and require scrolling, you can use a Table/List/Text with the SWT.V_SCROLL style.
- Report below - Hi Chris
I've tried three examples of the ScrolledComposite. Two examples are in the old javadoc (display 10 Buttons) and one in the new javadoc (two ScrolledComposite widgets and one button to add a button into each widget). All example are VERY slow on the iPAQ. I've tried SWT because the ScrollPane in the AWT implementation is also very slow. Then I've modified the first two examples in that way, that I'm placing the Components on my own and don't use a LayoutManager. The speed is much better and I can scroll through the page while it is repainted. With the LayoutManager you weren't even able to move the slider. If you need the code, look into the Javadocs of ScrolledComposite.
*** Bug 18441 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** TBD Post 2.0 - ScrolledComposite is currently unusable because on WinCE the child composite receives WM_SIZE events every time the scrollbar is pressed - causing the layout to relayout if a layout has been specified.
Fix to be checked-in after Eclipse 2.0 (currently frozen)
Feature on WinCE. In SetWindowPos, SWP_DRAWFRAME is equivalent to SWP_FRAMECHANGED. MSDN says that when this flag is specified, WinCE redraws the entire non-client area of the window, which may change the size of the client area. It has been verified that a WM_SIZE event is sent even if SWP_NOSIZE was set. The fix is to not specify SWP_DRAWFRAME when SWP_NOSIZE is specified.
Control.java void setBounds (int x, int y, int width, int height, int flags) { if (OS.IsWinCE) { /* PR18429 */ flags |= OS.SWP_NOZORDER | OS.SWP_NOACTIVATE; if ((flags & OS.SWP_NOSIZE) == 0) flags |= OS.SWP_DRAWFRAME; } else { flags |= OS.SWP_NOZORDER | OS.SWP_DRAWFRAME | OS.SWP_NOACTIVATE; } ... Fix now checked-in

Bug.Summery: DAV: CollectionHandle#mkdirs() assumes parent exists
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020530
Implementation of CollectionHandle#mkdirs() checks to see if the parent exists before trying to create a collection. In HTTP the parent need not exist for a resource to be created at a given URL (i.e. the URL namespace need not be 'consistent'). Fixed in builds > 20020531
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20020530
Implementation of CollectionHandle#mkdirs() checks to see if the parent exists before trying to create a collection. In HTTP the parent need not exist for a resource to be created at a given URL (i.e. the URL namespace need not be 'consistent'). Fixed in builds > 20020531

Bug.Summery: Empty boot path si not the same as default boot path

Lines.Line: - create a Java launch configuration,
- choose not to use the default path,
- and make the boot path empty,
- Uncheck use default boot path
Add
JRE to classpath
- Launch and notice command line doesn't show an empty -Xbootclasspath:
Now
add some other project to bootpath in config
- Launch and notice that now there is a -

Bug.WithStack:
When you
- create a Java launch configuration, - choose not to use the default path, - and make the boot path empty,
the vm is launched without -Xbootclasspath option, resulting in the default system class library to be used instead of an empty boot path.
This is most likely not a problem in practice, but I am not sure this is intended behavior. This is a bug. Fixed. Had to change API on
* AbstractJavaLaunchConfigurationDelegate#getBootpath(). It can now return null to indicate default BP, or an emptry array to indicate empty * VMRunnerConfiguration set/getBootClassPath - also accepts null/empty Please verify There is a problem here, that may be somewhat unrelated:
- Uncheck use default boot path - Add JRE to classpath - Launch and notice command line doesn't show an empty -Xbootclasspath: - Now add some other project to bootpath in config - Launch and notice that now there is a -
Xbootclasspath: entry, but it shows both the project and the JRE that was put on the classpath.
Note that if you uncheck use default bootpath, delete whatever entries are there, then launch, you do see the empty -Xbootclasspath: in the command line (event though launch fails because JRE lib can't be found) Fixed. please verify. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When you
- create a Java launch configuration, - choose not to use the default path, - and make the boot path empty,
the vm is launched without -Xbootclasspath option, resulting in the default system class library to be used instead of an empty boot path.
This is most likely not a problem in practice, but I am not sure this is intended behavior. This is a bug. Fixed. Had to change API on
* AbstractJavaLaunchConfigurationDelegate#getBootpath(). It can now return null to indicate default BP, or an emptry array to indicate empty * VMRunnerConfiguration set/getBootClassPath - also accepts null/empty Please verify There is a problem here, that may be somewhat unrelated:
- Uncheck use default boot path - Add JRE to classpath - Launch and notice command line doesn't show an empty -Xbootclasspath: - Now add some other project to bootpath in config - Launch and notice that now there is a -
Xbootclasspath: entry, but it shows both the project and the JRE that was put on the classpath.
Note that if you uncheck use default bootpath, delete whatever entries are there, then launch, you do see the empty -Xbootclasspath: in the command line (event though launch fails because JRE lib can't be found) Fixed. please verify. Verified.

Bug.Summery: cannot hit copy/paste in a row on multiple selection [ccp]
Bug.WithStack: in the java world you cannot hot copy/paste in a row if you have multiple items selected this could be allowed for items that have the same parent (as it is in the navigator) defer Chaning state from assigned later to resolved later. Assigned later got introduced by the last bug conversion and is not a supported Eclipse bug state. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack: in the java world you cannot hot copy/paste in a row if you have multiple items selected this could be allowed for items that have the same parent (as it is in the navigator) defer Chaning state from assigned later to resolved later. Assigned later got introduced by the last bug conversion and is not a supported Eclipse bug state. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: deleting multiple fields triggers multiple builds (if editor closed) [ccp]
Bug.WithStack:
we delete fields by calling 'delete' in a loop (unlike other members which we delete all in one go by using text edits)
this results in: . multiple builds when you have the editor closed . multiple local history entries
(not sure how to fix though) can you do it inside a workbench runnable? defer The workbench runnable might reduce the numbers of builds to one. Deleting a field is done via JDOM (AFAIK) which save the file.
So why don't we use the same code as we use to delete methods ? Adam, can you test if this still exists. If so we should ask Java Core how to avoid this. it was fixed today

Bug.Summery: Lauch fails after JRE changed (old one removed)

Lines.Line: 1. Created and used a launch configuration against a JRE (which was the
default) using the PDE launcher
2. Added a new JRE (upgraded to latest IBM) and made it the default
3. Removed the old one
4. Tried to launch the configuration from step 1

Bug.WithStack:
I performed the following steps 1. Created and used a launch configuration against a JRE (which was the default) using the PDE launcher 2. Added a new JRE (upgraded to latest IBM) and made it the default 3. Removed the old one 4. Tried to launch the configuration from step 1
I would expect it to either pick the default one or prompt that the JRE it was set to was gone. What happened was that the launch fails (leaves an entry in the debug view) with no message and no log. When I edit the launch configuration, it then shows me one of the existing ones (but not the default one, which is what I would expect). After I set the JRE, everything works fine. Moving to PDE. The java application launcher handles this case and reports an error to the user (missing JRE). The PDE lanucher should do the same. F3 candidate. Implemented - will detect missing JVM and report it as error.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I performed the following steps 1. Created and used a launch configuration against a JRE (which was the default) using the PDE launcher 2. Added a new JRE (upgraded to latest IBM) and made it the default 3. Removed the old one 4. Tried to launch the configuration from step 1
I would expect it to either pick the default one or prompt that the JRE it was set to was gone. What happened was that the launch fails (leaves an entry in the debug view) with no message and no log. When I edit the launch configuration, it then shows me one of the existing ones (but not the default one, which is what I would expect). After I set the JRE, everything works fine. Moving to PDE. The java application launcher handles this case and reports an error to the user (missing JRE). The PDE lanucher should do the same. F3 candidate. Implemented - will detect missing JVM and report it as error.

- Some personal tips to workaround it - I recommend avoiding the ScrolledComposite on PocketPC. - rearrange in different Composite instead when possible. If you have large/variable amount of data and require scrolling, you can use a Table/List/Text with the SWT.V_SCROLL style.
- Report below - Hi Chris
I've tried three examples of the ScrolledComposite. Two examples are in the old javadoc (display 10 Buttons) and one in the new javadoc (two ScrolledComposite widgets and one button to add a button into each widget). All example are VERY slow on the iPAQ. I've tried SWT because the ScrollPane in the AWT implementation is also very slow. Then I've modified the first two examples in that way, that I'm placing the Components on my own and don't use a LayoutManager. The speed is much better and I can scroll through the page while it is repainted. With the LayoutManager you weren't even able to move the slider. If you need the code, look into the Javadocs of ScrolledComposite.
Christophe Cornu wrote: > > Hi Bjoern, > > You probably found a bug. Can you open a bug report (product Platform - > Component SWT - OS Windows CE) with the test case? Let me know if you need > further info about this (or email me the test case) > Thanks! > > Chris Hi,
I want to write a small app for the iPAQ. Because sometimes I have to display more information than fits to the screen I need something like a ScrollPane. I've tried the ScrolledComposite example described in the javadoc (okay, for testing I'm using 100 labels). It works on the desktop but when I run this example on the iPAQ it's VERY slow. Touching the arrow it lasts 2 seconds to readraw the screen, moving the slider lasts even more (>8sec). The first time I thought my iPAQ crashed because nothing happened. Is this a bad example to get a scrollable workspace on the iPAQ? Is there another way to get this thing working?
Info: iPAQ with pocketPC 2002 swt-win32-2040.dll j9
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 18429 ***

Bug.Summery: Coolbar doesn't shift items correctly

Lines.Line: 1. Turn on autobuilding.
2. Position the sets of buttons in the coolbar such that all buttons are
visible and all sets of buttons are left-justified (this is standard
layout).
3. Turn off autobuilding. The "build" button is added to the leftmost set
of buttons, but since there isn't enough room for it, we create a chevron
which contains the build button.
4. Now try to fix up your layout so that it looks like it did in step 2
(all buttons visible). Grab the set of buttons to the right of the chevron
and drag it to the right until the chevron disappears and the build button
is visible. Note that when you drag the buttons to the right, the *next*
set of buttons to the right doesn't move, so the 2nd set of buttons now has
a chevron.

Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020530 Linux-GTK
After the user expands a set of buttons, they have to fix up every set of buttons to the right of the expanded set. This is the wrong behavior.
For an example: 1. Turn on autobuilding. 2. Position the sets of buttons in the coolbar such that all buttons are visible and all sets of buttons are left-justified (this is standard layout). 3. Turn off autobuilding. The "build" button is added to the leftmost set of buttons, but since there isn't enough room for it, we create a chevron which contains the build button. 4. Now try to fix up your layout so that it looks like it did in step 2 (all buttons visible). Grab the set of buttons to the right of the chevron and drag it to the right until the chevron disappears and the build button is visible. Note that when you drag the buttons to the right, the *next* set of buttons to the right doesn't move, so the 2nd set of buttons now has a chevron.
The user shouldn't have to reposition every single set of buttons just to make one set bigger. When a set of buttons is dragged to the right, it should push along sets of buttons to it's right. Agree it's not very friendly behavior, but it looks like it's platform behavior on Windows and was therefore emulated on Linux. Not sure what could be done here. Reassigning to SWT. We will likely not do anything about this until after R2.0 ships.
The behavior is correct! Dragging a CoolItem should not move the next CoolItem at its right until the CoolItem been dragged reach it's minimum width.
On Eclipse you can use the option "Reset ToolBar Layout" in this case.
I see it's not a friendly behavior, unfortunately there's nothing I can do. "Dragging a CoolItem should not move the next CoolItem at its right until the CoolItem been dragged reach it's minimum width."
This is true, but it's not what Eclipse does. You can keep dragging an item to the right past the minimum width such that you start collapsing buttons. See comment above. The bug is that the coolbar doesn't behave as described. I think you are confusing "preferred width" and "minimum width" for CoolItem. Both values are set by the application, usually they are:
"preferred width" -- shows the whole ToolBar (without chevron). "minimum width" -- shows only one ToolItem (*has the chevron*).
When dragging a CoolItem it only move another CoolItem when the minimum width is reached (after you get the items collapse).
Please, perform the same test on your Windows Eclipse, or even better, test it on IE. You will see that the emulated CoolBar is right.
The Windows toolbar (the main toolbar in Win98 and Win2K) behaves as I've requested for buttons. It only behaves like Eclipse for other toolbar items like the task list and the toolbars which contain text and buttons, such as the "Desktop" toolbar.
Emulating the behavior of Microsoft programs may be what we want to do on Windows (and I'd even argue against that), but it seems wrong for other platforms (Linux).

Bug.Summery: [Ant 1.5Beta1] Override warning
Bug.WithStack:
As I need a feature of the 1.5 version of Ant, I tried to simply replace the ant.jar and ...optional.jar files in the ant plugin folder. It seems to work fine, except for a warning I get every time I execute a build script:
"Trying to override old definition of task copy"
This even happens with a build script as simple as
<project default="all"> <target name="all"/> </project> That happens because inside Eclipse we override the copy task so that when copying a file/folder, all its attributes (read-only, hidden, permission, etc...) are copied as well. It seems to work OK but we have not done any extensive tests. Since we copied and modified the copy task from Ant 1.4.1, if the task has changed between 1.4.1 and 1.5 we might miss new functionalities and/or bug fixes. It should be addressed after Eclipse 2.0 and Ant 1.5 are released. Suggest defer. So are you saying that the copy task will work differently wether used inside or outside of eclipse? I don't think this is a good idea, as it could cause subtile problems when using a script in both ways. If I develop an Ant script inside of Eclipse, I would expect it to behave in exactly the same way when used "standalone" (as long as I don't use any of the eclipse tasks). Yes, it will be different. Deferring. Investigate post 2.0 either removing or renaming our Copy task. Reopening for possible removal of the Eclipse version of the copy task. Needs investigation. Fixed and released. Removed EclipseCopy Ant task.

As I need a feature of the 1.5 version of Ant, I tried to simply replace the ant.jar and ...optional.jar files in the ant plugin folder. It seems to work fine, except for a warning I get every time I execute a build script:

Bug.Summery: Default container entry

Lines.Line: - Uncheck use default boot path
- Add
JRE to classpath
- Launch and notice command line doesn't show an empty -Xbootclasspath:
- Now
add some other project to bootpath in config
- Launch and notice that now there is a -
Xbootclasspath: entry, but it shows

classpath.

Bug.WithStack:
Request from Martin:
There is a public static IClasspathEntry getJREVariableEntry()
can I have the same for the default container entry? public static IClasspathEntry getJREContainerEntry()
(The preference page gets a combo were you can select the classpath entry (var / container) that is added to a newly created Java project) Fixed. Added #getDefaultJREContainerEntry. Please verify. Verified. There is a problem here, that may be somewhat unrelated:
- Uncheck use default boot path - Add JRE to classpath - Launch and notice command line doesn't show an empty -Xbootclasspath: - Now add some other project to bootpath in config - Launch and notice that now there is a - Xbootclasspath: entry, but it shows both the project and the JRE that was put on the classpath.
Note that if you uncheck use default bootpath, delete whatever entries are there, then launch, you do see the empty -Xbootclasspath: in the command line (event though launch fails because JRE lib can't be found). This bug is fixed & verified. I annotated and re-opened the wrong bug. Ignore previous comment. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Request from Martin:

can I have the same for the default container entry? public static IClasspathEntry getJREContainerEntry()
(The preference page gets a combo were you can select the classpath entry (var / container) that is added to a newly created Java project) Fixed. Added #getDefaultJREContainerEntry. Please verify. Verified. There is a problem here, that may be somewhat unrelated:
- Uncheck use default boot path - Add JRE to classpath - Launch and notice command line doesn't show an empty -Xbootclasspath: - Now add some other project to bootpath in config - Launch and notice that now there is a - Xbootclasspath: entry, but it shows both the project and the JRE that was put on the classpath.
Note that if you uncheck use default bootpath, delete whatever entries are there, then launch, you do see the empty -Xbootclasspath: in the command line (event though launch fails because JRE lib can't be found). This bug is fixed & verified. I annotated and re-opened the wrong bug. Ignore previous comment. Verified.

Bug.Summery: [Tasks] Global tasks are removed when filtering
Bug.WithStack: Global tasks are attached to the root resource, which is not visible. the only way to see these tasks are to filter by 'on any resource'. This is strange from a user perspective because you can explicitly exclude global tasks but never explicitly include them. This is an implementation side effect that global tasks (that the user sees as not on any resource in particular) are actually tacked on to this invisible root resource as the implementation has no place else to put them. Is this still an issue in 3.2? As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack: Global tasks are attached to the root resource, which is not visible. the only way to see these tasks are to filter by 'on any resource'. This is strange from a user perspective because you can explicitly exclude global tasks but never explicitly include them. This is an implementation side effect that global tasks (that the user sees as not on any resource in particular) are actually tacked on to this invisible root resource as the implementation has no place else to put them. Is this still an issue in 3.2? As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Deleting project doesn't remove pkg fragment root in another project
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020530
Deleting (or closing) org.eclipse.swt.win32 doesn't update org.eclipse.swt. It still shows the package fragment root /ws/win32/swt.jar. This is a delta problem. The removal of the package fragment root is not reported. Fixed by looking at all package fragment roots and generating the corresponding deltas when a project is added/removed. Verified, both closing/opening is behaving ok.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20020530
Deleting (or closing) org.eclipse.swt.win32 doesn't update org.eclipse.swt. It still shows the package fragment root /ws/win32/swt.jar. This is a delta problem. The removal of the package fragment root is not reported. Fixed by looking at all package fragment roots and generating the corresponding deltas when a project is added/removed. Verified, both closing/opening is behaving ok.

Bug.Summery: [TM UI] support integrated progress monitoring in Site Explorer
Bug.WithStack:
It would be nice to have a explorer/netscape progress bar at the bottom of the site explorer which would allow cancellation. Also it could allow updating the view in a non-blocking thread. I've already added some support to the target ui model elements for this but there is more work to be done in creating the progress parts and testing.
This would also allow cancellation of long running operations. However, with a reasonable timeout value progress is, in my view, an enhancement. As long as operations timeout reasonably. This is the behavior of most browsers, for example the file explorer on windows. later Reopening This bug has not been touched in 2 years. Closing as WONTFIX. If you feel this bug is important, feel free to reopen it.

Bug.Summery: [Tasks] Task view should be split into two distinct views.
Bug.WithStack: The task view should be split into a task view and a problems view. Currently these are merged which raises a number of issues. Delete is confusing as problems are read only. Filtering and presentation is confusing as problems don't have priorities and tasks don't have severities. Users interested in navigating build problems that otherwise don't make any use of the task functionality could do without seeing the new task button always at the forefront of the ui, or other task specific functionality in the context menus, and visa versa for users that like to log tasks to themselves but otherwise use other methods for navigating errors. the filter dialog is unnecessarily complex because of this forced merging as well. *** Bug 22403 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** fixed
Bug.WithOutStack: The task view should be split into a task view and a problems view. Currently these are merged which raises a number of issues. Delete is confusing as problems are read only. Filtering and presentation is confusing as problems don't have priorities and tasks don't have severities. Users interested in navigating build problems that otherwise don't make any use of the task functionality could do without seeing the new task button always at the forefront of the ui, or other task specific functionality in the context menus, and visa versa for users that like to log tasks to themselves but otherwise use other methods for navigating errors. the filter dialog is unnecessarily complex because of this forced merging as well. *** Bug 22403 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** fixed

Bug.Summery: [Tasks] Task view does not update filter correctly when a selection provider gives on items
Bug.WithStack:
with navigator and package view both open, select no items on navigator (ctrl click the current selection off if necessary), activate package view and select some items. adjust task filter to filter by one of the selection options. now activate navigator view. notice no change. this is due to the fact task view has intentionally introduced a bug: i.e. to only change the selection when the active part is an editor, or a view providing a structured selection of one or more resources. the motivation for this i believe is to force a lazy behavior so the task view doesn't flicker too much when activating views that don't contribute to the task view. the design problem is that the task view is proactively attaches itself to the selections of the active view without any knowledge if that view can provide a meaningful selection. outline view, for instance, returns a selection of 0 items even when there is no outline available, where other views return null for their selection. without a formal contract between the task view and the active view for the active view to supply resources, the task view needs to be able to intelligently determine whether or not a selection is providing resources. it cannot do this with a null or empty selection.
(ignore this comment: bugzilla test) (ignore this comment: bugzilla test 2)
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 6611 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
with navigator and package view both open, select no items on navigator (ctrl click the current selection off if necessary), activate package view and select some items. adjust task filter to filter by one of the selection options. now activate navigator view. notice no change. this is due to the fact task view has intentionally introduced a bug: i.e. to only change the selection when the active part is an editor, or a view providing a structured selection of one or more resources. the motivation for this i believe is to force a lazy behavior so the task view doesn't flicker too much when activating views that don't contribute to the task view. the design problem is that the task view is proactively attaches itself to the selections of the active view without any knowledge if that view can provide a meaningful selection. outline view, for instance, returns a selection of 0 items even when there is no outline available, where other views return null for their selection. without a formal contract between the task view and the active view for the active view to supply resources, the task view needs to be able to intelligently determine whether or not a selection is providing resources. it cannot do this with a null or empty selection.
(ignore this comment: bugzilla test) (ignore this comment: bugzilla test 2)

Bug.Summery: Radio bullet on Packages view's Filters... item [filters]

Lines.Line: - Enable Filters (check with simple toggle behaviour)
- Configure Filters (no check, enabled only when Enable Filters is checked)

Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020530
The Filters... item on the view menu has a radio bullet, even though there are no other items in this group to choose from. it is used to indicate that there is an active filter. Otherwise there is no indication whether there is a filter active. Usually a radio bullet indicates a 1 of N choice. To indicate whether something is active or not, recommend using a checkbox. However, usually a checkbox item simply toggles state, and does bring up extra UI. Could have two items: - Enable Filters (check with simple toggle behaviour) - Configure Filters (no check, enabled only when Enable Filters is checked)
I think having two items will confuse the user. I opt to use a check box instead of a "radio" button. Agree with Dirk. Changed RADIO to CHECK Available in builds > 20020814
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20020530
The Filters... item on the view menu has a radio bullet, even though there are no other items in this group to choose from. it is used to indicate that there is an active filter. Otherwise there is no indication whether there is a filter active. Usually a radio bullet indicates a 1 of N choice. To indicate whether something is active or not, recommend using a checkbox. However, usually a checkbox item simply toggles state, and does bring up extra UI. Could have two items: - Enable Filters (check with simple toggle behaviour) - Configure Filters (no check, enabled only when Enable Filters is checked)
I think having two items will confuse the user. I opt to use a check box instead of a "radio" button. Agree with Dirk. Changed RADIO to CHECK Available in builds > 20020814

The Members view of the Java Browsing Perspective does not follow the cursor movement when the feature "Synchronize outline selection on cursor move" is on. The Members view has an outline selection, so that feature must apply to it as well.
I cannot see the diferences between the Members view and the Outline view except the name and the fact that the Outline view shows the Package and Class names.
In my opinion and for the sake of homogeneity this should to be fixed. issue understood, cannot fix for 2.0 Kai, if we want the same behaviour for the outline view does this require some actions from the Java editor. Sorry I meant members view >I cannot see the diferences between the Members view and the Outline view >except the name and the fact that the Outline view shows the Package and >Class names.
Major differences: - the Members view can work without an editor - the Members view can show the content of any select CU or type
I agree with your request.
Post 2.1
This is not that easy to fix because selection changed event is not sent upon cursor movements i.e. when the offset changes while the length is 0 (reason is performance: all selection listeners would be triggered while typing in an editor).
TextViewer now sends a (delayed) selection changed event upon caret position changes.
Adapted browsing views to this.
Available in builds > N20030602
FYI: The text infrastructure now sends post selection events. Due bug 39511 the fix for this bug is currently broken.

Bug.Summery: Wizard left displayed with no busy cursor for long time
Bug.WithStack:
Create a new plugin project. Select Hello World template. Accept all defaults. Press finish. Wizard creates plugin, then cursor changes to non-busy, and wizard is left displayed for about 5-7 seconds. This was puzzling and I started clicking on finish again, but then realized the problem was just that the busy cursor should have been shown.
In summary, the busy cursor changes to normal too long before the wizard closes. The problem must have been fixed at some point.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Create a new plugin project. Select Hello World template. Accept all defaults. Press finish. Wizard creates plugin, then cursor changes to non-busy, and wizard is left displayed for about 5-7 seconds. This was puzzling and I started clicking on finish again, but then realized the problem was just that the busy cursor should have been shown.
In summary, the busy cursor changes to normal too long before the wizard closes. The problem must have been fixed at some point.

Bug.Summery: [ExternalTools] Minor: output not always in right order
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020531
Due to implementation issues of ProgramRunner, if an Ant builder is run right after a program (.exe or .bat) builder, the output of the Ant builder sometimes shows on the log console before the output of the program builder. They ARE executed in the right order however. When we switch to using the debug console, it will split up the log properly to show only the selected external tool running in the process view.
Note: new external tool work is not yet released to the head stream and won't for a while yet. This bug has not been fixed and should not have been closed. Program output and Ant output is now in seperate consoles (i.e. seperate documents in the same view), when using new launch config support. Please verify, Darin S Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20020531
Due to implementation issues of ProgramRunner, if an Ant builder is run right after a program (.exe or .bat) builder, the output of the Ant builder sometimes shows on the log console before the output of the program builder. Bug.Summery: IE6 causes conflict with SWT.APPLICATION_MODAL on Windows 98

Lines.Line: 1) Start Windows 98 on a machine with IE 5 or earlier
2) Select a file
3) Hit delete - a prompter comes up
4) Select an non Eclipse window and drag it over the dialog
5) Select the Eclipse parent window in the tasks list - the dialog and window
are given focus
6) Start Windows 98 on a machine with IE 62) Select a file
3) Hit delete - a prompter comes up
4) Select an non Eclipse window and drag it over the dialog
5) Select the Eclipse parent window in the tasks list - the dialog only is
given focus and the window stays in the backgroud.
3) Hit delete - a prompter comes up
4) Select an non Eclipse window and drag it over the dialog
5) Select the Eclipse parent window in the tasks list - the dialog only is
given focus and the window stays in the backgroud.

Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020531
When IE 6 is installed on Windows 98 it replaces the task bar with one of its own (according to Dave Thomson). When this occurs the focus behaviour of shells with modality set to SWT.APPLICATION_MODAL changes.
STEPS 1) Start Windows 98 on a machine with IE 5 or earlier 2) Select a file 3) Hit delete - a prompter comes up 4) Select an non Eclipse window and drag it over the dialog 5) Select the Eclipse parent window in the tasks list - the dialog and window are given focus 6) Start Windows 98 on a machine with IE 62) Select a file 3) Hit delete - a prompter comes up 4) Select an non Eclipse window and drag it over the dialog 5) Select the Eclipse parent window in the tasks list - the dialog only is given focus and the window stays in the backgroud.
I don't have a good pure SWT example of this yet as I am still trying to find the condition that makes this happen. Is the dialog a child of the shell? If it isn't there's no reason for the shell to come to the front when the dialog does.
In any case, this seems like a minor issue to me. Do you believe this needs to be addressed for R2.0? The dialog shell is the child of the window shell.
I do not believe this is a major issue for 2.0 as the user loses no information - i.e. the modal shell is the one they see so there are no mystery dialog preventing them working. Basically, I believe you are seeing something which would be true for every windows app: Installing the new IE changes the behavior. As long as this isn't causing anyone any real grief, I'm not even going to look at it until after R2.0.
This is not an issue for 2.0. However I believe it does expose a bug in our code. Not ALL of our dialogs exhibit this behavior - in fact most of them work correctly. Other applications also work correctly and are not affected by IE 6.
Only certain of our dialogs (such as the one in the test case) work incorrectly, so it could indicate a problem with the way the particular dialog is create or its relationship to the underlying shell.
The reason I asked the question "Is the dialog a child of the parent?" is because I have had cases in the past where we tried to debug one of these but eventually proved that the dialog's parent was null (even though we were told by the UI team that it was not). If this is true, then the new "IE 6" specific behavior is the correct behavior. This would certainly explain the fact that some dialogs exhibit the behavior and some do not.
Another possibility would be that the dialogs that work are the built in dialogs, and all "hand rolled" dialogs are broken, in which case the problem would definately be in our code.
In any case, as previously stated. This bug is LATER.
Confirmed that we are setting the parent shell properly. I saw the problem with the Navigator on my home machine (XP), but not at work (also XP). Both have IE 6.
Moving from Later. Tod, can you try this again with the "32770" changes? Works with the 32270 changes in build 20020911. Closing.

Build 20020531

Bug.Summery: backwards compatibility support for nl/fr_FR_EURO
Bug.WithStack:
In Eclipse 1.0, Core runtime's "$nl$" mechanism was implemented incorrectly. A path like "$nl$/foo.txt" would end up looking in the following locale-specific locations under the plug-in (including fragments), assuming the current locale is "fr_FR_EURO": nl/fr_FR_EURO/foo.txt nl/fr_FR/foo.txt nl/fr/foo.txt foo.text This is incorrect. It should have been looking in this sequence of locations: nl/fr/FR/EURO/foo.txt nl/fr/FR/foo.txt nl/fr/foo.txt foo.text
This problem has been corrected For Eclipse 2.0
However, for backwards compatibility, the old 1.0 way should be supported as well (considered as deprecated). The implementation should look in this order: nl/fr/FR/EURO/foo.txt nl/fr_FR_EURO/foo.txt nl/fr/FR/foo.txt nl/fr_FR/foo.txt nl/fr/foo.txt foo.text Consider for FP2. Requires changes in: PluginDescriptor.buildVariants PluginDescriptor.findNL
Fixed. Added test cases. Reviewed. Released. Closing.

It should have been looking in this sequence of locations: nl/fr/FR/EURO/foo.txt nl/fr/FR/foo.txt nl/fr/foo.txt foo.text

Bug.Summery: Why is Run... dialog not preinitialized with runtime workbench config?

Lines.Line: (1) Debug UI adds new API to set the configuration to be launched when the
debug button is pressed (this is the same as what gets selected when the dialog
is opened).
(2) PDE creates launch config when a new plugin project is created, and uses
the new API to set the config to launch

Bug.WithStack:
Build 0531 Create a new plugin project using wizard. Select Plugin with a view template. Accept all defaults. Finish Run->Run... You are presented with a confusing dialog with a grayed out run button. Close the dialog. Run it using Run->Run As->Runtime workbench After it opens, close it. Now try it the first way again. Run->Run... This time, Run is not grayed, and you can just press it and it works. Question: Should it not appear this way the first time so a new user can just accept the defaults and press Run? When using the shortcut, a new launch config instance is created and initialized with defaults. When you use Run->Run... again, this new instance is now shown in the tree and selected. Selecting the instance causes the 'Run' button to enable (and the tabs to show the config parameters). The first time you select 'Run->Run...' the dialog does not know what launch type are after. However, shortcuts registered for 'Run->Run As' know what to do.
I am moving this to Debug because they control the dialog behaviour. When the launch dialog is opened, it selects the configuration that was last launched. In the use case above, the first time the dialog is opened, there are no configurations to select from.
Poposal: (1) Debug UI adds new API to set the configuration to be launched when the debug button is pressed (this is the same as what gets selected when the dialog is opened). (2) PDE creates launch config when a new plugin project is created, and uses the new API to set the config to launch
This solution is even better in that the user can just press "run" or "debug" without having to see the dialog. Adding Dejan as CC There has been some disagreement on an API that can interfere with the launch history. If there are launches in the workbench, then clients should not be able to change the launch history/expected behavior of the run/debug buttons.
Proposal is on hold. No changes planned at this point. The suggested action to to use "Run/Debug As -> Runtime Workbench".
No changes planned for 2.0. Closing. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 0531 Create a new plugin project using wizard. Select Plugin with a view template. Accept all defaults. Finish Run->Run... You are presented with a confusing dialog with a grayed out run button. Close the dialog. Run it using Run->Run As->Runtime workbench After it opens, close it. Now try it the first way again. Run->Run... This time, Run is not grayed, and you can just press it and it works. Question: Should it not appear this way the first time so a new user can just accept the defaults and press Run? When using the shortcut, a new launch config instance is created and initialized with defaults. When you use Run->Run... again, this new instance is now shown in the tree and selected. Selecting the instance causes the 'Run' button to enable (and the tabs to show the config parameters). The first time you select 'Run->Run...' the dialog does not know what launch type are after. However, shortcuts registered for 'Run->Run As' know what to do.
I am moving this to Debug because they control the dialog behaviour. When the launch dialog is opened, it selects the configuration that was last launched. In the use case above, the first time the dialog is opened, there are no configurations to select from.
Poposal: (1) Debug UI adds new API to set the configuration to be launched when the debug button is pressed (this is the same as what gets selected when the dialog is opened). (2) PDE creates launch config when a new plugin project is created, and uses the new API to set the config to launch
This solution is even better in that the user can just press "run" or "debug" without having to see the dialog. Adding Dejan as CC There has been some disagreement on an API that can interfere with the launch history. If there are launches in the workbench, then clients should not be able to change the launch history/expected behavior of the run/debug buttons.
Proposal is on hold. No changes planned at this point. The suggested action to to use "Run/Debug As -> Runtime Workbench".
No changes planned for 2.0. Closing. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Launch config: getting asked to save changes when there where no changes

Lines.Line: 1) execute Run As>JUnit test on a test case
2) open the launch config dialog -> the newly created config is selected
3) click on another config
->you get prompted whether you want to save changes

Bug.WithStack:
1) execute Run As>JUnit test on a test case 2) open the launch config dialog -> the newly created config is selected 3) click on another config ->you get prompted whether you want to save changes
Verified that the same attributes are set. What is special about the JUnit launch config is that the tab group initializes the default run perspective to "null", i.e. no change.
However, when doing the compare only values supplied by the tabs are taken into consideration. See LaunchConfigurationDialog.updateWorkingCopyFromPages(); The defaults set by the tabgroup itself are not considered. Hence there is a difference. The launch configs compared are (without the qualifcation)
MAIN_TYPE=junit.samples.VectorTest, PROJECT_ATTR=JUnit, KEEPRUNNING_ATTR=false, source_locator_id=org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui.javaSourceLocator, target_debug_perspective=perspective_default}
MAIN_TYPE=junit.samples.VectorTest, KEEPRUNNING_ATTR=false, PROJECT_ATTR=JUnit, target_run_perspective=perspective_none, source_locator_id=org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui.javaSourceLocator, target_debug_perspective=perspective_default
As you can see the run perspective is missing in one config. should use IDebugUIConstants.PERSPECTIVE_NONE rather than "null" to indicate no perspective switching. problem was that perspective attribute was set to the "" string and not to IDebugUIConstants.PERSPECTIVE_NONE.
The PDE RuntimeWorkbenchShortCut has the same problem. In createConfiguration change:
wc.setAttribute(IDebugUIConstants.ATTR_TARGET_RUN_PERSPECTIVE, (String) null); to
wc.setAttribute(IDebugUIConstants.ATTR_TARGET_RUN_PERSPECTIVE, IDebugUIConstants.PERSPECTIVE_NONE);
Moving to PDE pls try integrate the fix for F2 Done.

Bug.Summery: Stack trace in console on run if runtime workbench already running

Stacktrace.Reason: org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException: The platform metadata area is already in use by another platform instance, or there was a failure in deleting the old lock file. If no other platform instances are running, delete the lock file (C:\WINDOWS\Desktop\0531\eclipse\runtime-workspace\.metadata\.lock) and try starting the platform again.

Bug.WithStack:
Build 0531 Create a new plugin project using wizard. Select Plugin with a view template. Accept all defaults. Finish Run->Run As->Runtime workbench Wait until it starts. Run it again. Following appears in console (unfriendly). Question: Why don't we have a message dialog that tells the user that a runtime workbench is already running instead of dumping a stack trace to the console?
java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException: org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException: The platform metadata area is already in use by another platform instance, or there was a failure in deleting the old lock file. If no other platform instances are running, delete the lock file (C:\WINDOWS\Desktop\0531\eclipse\runtime-workspace\.metadata\.lock) and try starting the platform again. at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.createLockFile (InternalPlatform.java:195) at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.loaderStartup (InternalPlatform.java:546) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Native Method) at org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.startup (InternalBootLoader.java:873) at org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.run (InternalBootLoader.java:732) at org.eclipse.core.boot.BootLoader.run(BootLoader.java:432) at EclipseRuntimeLauncher.main(EclipseRuntimeLauncher.java:24) Exception in thread "main" The message is only created as a log entry by Core. For a while, PDE had an elaborate mechanism whereby it kept track of running instances and prevented the user from launching the run-time instance on the same workspace twice. This mechanism was dependent on events from the launcher and was not robust enough. For example, if the run-time instance crashes or is otherwise unnaturally terminated, PDE is not notified. After that PDE would prevent users from launching the instance. We had to remove the support because the problems it created outweighted the problem it was trying to solve.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 0531 Create a new plugin project using wizard. Select Plugin with a view template. Accept all defaults. Finish Run->Run As->Runtime workbench Wait until it starts. Run it again. Following appears in console (unfriendly). Question: Why don't we have a message dialog that tells the user that a runtime workbench is already running instead of dumping a stack trace to the console?
Exception in thread "main" The message is only created as a log entry by Core. For a while, PDE had an elaborate mechanism whereby it kept track of running instances and prevented the user from launching the run-time instance on the same workspace twice. This mechanism was dependent on events from the launcher and was not robust enough. For example, if the run-time instance crashes or is otherwise unnaturally terminated, PDE is not notified. After that PDE would prevent users from launching the instance. We had to remove the support because the problems it created outweighted the problem it was trying to solve.

Bug.Summery: Ant - cannot use script if no main task is defined
Bug.WithStack:
Build F1 This used to work a few weeks (months?) ago.
Use an ant script which defines multiple tasks - but no one called "main". Select the script in the navigator, right click, select 'run ant' Select one task - the console thinks it is task (2), not (1) Run it. It fails. The log console displays: Target `main' does not exist in this project. at org.apache.tools.ant.Project.tsort(Project.java:873) at org.apache.tools.ant.Project.topoSort(Project.java:818) at org.apache.tools.ant.Project.executeTarget(Project.java:594) at org.apache.tools.ant.Project.executeTargets(Project.java:560) at org.eclipse.ant.internal.core.ant.InternalAntRunner.run (InternalAntRunner.java:269) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Native Method) at org.eclipse.ant.core.AntRunner.run(AntRunner.java:155) at org.eclipse.ant.core.AntRunner.run(AntRunner.java:168) at org.eclipse.ui.externaltools.internal.core.AntFileRunner.execute (AntFileRunner.java:53) at org.eclipse.ui.externaltools.internal.core.DefaultRunnerContext.executeRunner (DefaultRunnerContext.java:207) at org.eclipse.ui.externaltools.internal.core.DefaultRunnerContext.run (DefaultRunnerContext.java:257) at org.eclipse.ui.externaltools.internal.ui.AntLaunchWizard$1.run (AntLaunchWizard.java:117) at org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run (ModalContext.java:98)

Bug.Summery: [ExternalTools] Locations with spaces cause some tools to fail
Bug.WithStack:
When location arguments contain spaces, some tools don't work properly.
For example, create a project in your workspace named "Test Project" (the space is important). Create a file "abc.txt" in the project. Create a simple tool with location c:\windows\write.exe and with the argument ${resource_loc}. Select the file abc.txt, then run the tool. Write will try to find the file <workspace location>/Test and fail. This is pretty important. I think the different Runtime.exec methods handle arguments with spaces differently. If I remember correctly, the ones which take an array of strings work better than the ones which take a single string. Might have to quote args with spaces ourselves.
Need to ensure we also handle user-specified quotes properly. *** Bug 19515 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Code changes done by Ryan. Checked by Simon and Tod Verified in build 20020610.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When location arguments contain spaces, some tools don't work properly.
For example, create a project in your workspace named "Test Project" (the space is important). Create a file "abc.txt" in the project. Write will try to find the file <workspace location>/Test and fail. This is pretty important. I think the different Runtime.exec methods handle arguments with spaces differently. If I remember correctly, the ones which take an array of strings work better than the ones which take a single string. Might have to quote args with spaces ourselves.
Need to ensure we also handle user-specified quotes properly. *** Bug 19515 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Code changes done by Ryan. Checked by Simon and Tod Verified in build 20020610.

Bug.Summery: [import] Plugin import wizard does not allow plugins of different versions

Lines.Line: a) user will get the warning anyway
b) next logical step would be to install that EE.
Created attachment 153662
WIP Patch
1) Remove the current yes/yes to all/no/no to all/cancel prompting.
2) Before starting to import individual bundles, scan the workspace models for bundles with the same symbolic name as a bundle being imported.
3) If there are any bundle name conflicts, open a dialog with a checkbox table. List all bundles with the same name along with their version and project name.
4) The user can deselect bundles they do not want overwritten (a single import could overwrite multiple projects).
5) Delete the selected projects.

6) Import the plug-ins, if there is still a project with the same default name, append the version (without qualifier). If that project exists, make the project name be "<symbolic name> (<version>) #" with increasing values of #.
1) The dialog opens even when there are no conflicts
2) The check box should be part of the plug-in name column (see Installed JREs pref page)
3) There should be an icon on the first column (you can use the general PDE label provider just like the plugin import detailed page does)
4) The first column should be "Name" or "Plug-in" not symbolic name
5) The first column is too small, you can probably have the columns take equal sizes
6) Select all and deselect all buttons should be underneath, not beside the table. (see the dialog that offers to save multiple dirty editors when closing Eclipse).
7) When people see columns with headers, they generally expect to be able to click on them to sort by that column.
8) All entries in the dialog should be checked by default
9) Filter box should search anywhere in the name (see the plugin import detail page)
- if yes import with same name as in workspace (overwrite existing)
- if no import as "P (x.y.z)"

I don't think we need another option: it is already possible to select two versions of the same bundle if 'Show latest version of plug-ins only' is unchecked and if I do so, the last one wins (overwrites the first one).
The following small change to the initially proposed solution might do the trick:
When importing plug-in 'P' check if that bundle is already in the workspace with the same version (without qualifier) - if yes import with same name as in workspace (overwrite existing) - if no import as "P (x.y.z)" Darin and I came up with an alternate proposal:
1) Remove the current yes/yes to all/no/no to all/cancel prompting. 2) Before starting to import individual bundles, scan the workspace models for bundles with the same symbolic name as a bundle being imported. 3) If there are any bundle name conflicts, open a dialog with a checkbox table. List all bundles with the same name along with their version and project name. 4) The user can deselect bundles they do not want overwritten (a single import could overwrite multiple projects). 5) Delete the selected projects. 6) Import the plug-ins, if there is still a project with the same default name, append the version (without qualifier). If that project exists, make the project name be "<symbolic name> (<version>) #" with increasing values of #.
This solution makes the import depend on bundle names rather than project names, which feels more natural as project can be called anything. The user also has a fair amount of control over what they delete. Ankur, if we go forward with the proposal in comment #32 would you have time to work on this?

>I don't like spaces in project names. Could the projects be named as proposed >in comment 0, e.g. like this (stuff in [] only to disambiguate): And I don't like underscores in the name ;-) but I agree that unless there are ambiguities we only want the symbolic name like I proposed in my solution. In case of dis-ambiguities we should simply use the same rendering as PDE uses in the import and target pref page: symblicName (x.y.z.qualifier) where the "(...)" is rendered using qualifier color (see also bug 295827). There's a difference between rendering on the Target Platform page and choice of project name.
For rendering, the gray (x.y.z.qualifier) is a good way to add more information to bundle names. But the project name should be as close as possible to the original bundle name (after all, it is still an *import* operation), so the most obvious choice is the format used in the original jar names (where the version is also appended with an underscore). >so the >most obvious choice is the format used in the original jar names (where the >version is also appended with an underscore). I disagree that the JAR name is the obvious choice for a project name but I agree that we can't use gray decoration here i.e. the created project name should contain the additional qualifications and should be rendered in normal color. Pinging zx, sometime we should discuss what could be done here. This could become more of an issue when we ship version 3 and 4 of org.junit. I don't think we need another option: it is already possible to select two versions of the same bundle if 'Show latest version of plug-ins only' is unchecked and if I do so, the last one wins (overwrites the first one).
The following small change to the initially proposed solution might do the trick:
When importing plug-in 'P' check if that bundle is already in the workspace with the same version (without qualifier) - if yes import with same name as in workspace (overwrite existing) - if no import as "P (x.y.z)" Darin and I came up with an alternate proposal:
1) Remove the current yes/yes to all/no/no to all/cancel prompting. 2) Before starting to import individual bundles, scan the workspace models for bundles with the same symbolic name as a bundle being imported. 3) If there are any bundle name conflicts, open a dialog with a checkbox table. List all bundles with the same name along with their version and project name. 4) The user can deselect bundles they do not want overwritten (a single import could overwrite multiple projects). 5) Delete the selected projects. 6) Import the plug-ins, if there is still a project with the same default name, append the version (without qualifier). If that project exists, make the project name be "<symbolic name> (<version>) #" with increasing values of #.
This solution makes the import depend on bundle names rather than project names, which feels more natural as project can be called anything. The user also has a fair amount of control over what they delete. Ankur, if we go forward with the proposal in comment #32 would you have time to work on this?
Though I'm considering finding time to work on it, because it is < 20,000 and over 7 years old! Could the projects be named as proposed >in comment 0, e.g. like this (stuff in [] only to disambiguate): And I don't like underscores in the name ;-) but I agree that unless there are ambiguities we only want the symbolic name like I proposed in my solution. In case of dis-ambiguities we should simply use the same rendering as PDE uses in the import and target pref page: symblicName (x.y.z.qualifier) where the "(...)" is rendered using qualifier color (see also bug 295827). There's a difference between rendering on the Target Platform page and choice of project name.
For rendering, the gray (x.y.z.qualifier) is a good way to add more information to bundle names. But the project name should be as close as possible to the original bundle name (after all, it is still an *import* operation), so the most obvious choice is the format used in the original jar names (where the version is also appended with an underscore). >so the >most obvious choice is the format used in the original jar names (where the >version is also appended with an underscore). I disagree that the JAR name is the obvious choice for a project name but I agree that we can't use gray decoration here i.e. the created project name should contain the additional qualifications and should be rendered in normal color.
